column16: Suggest to add RECOMMENDED and OPTIONAL.
column17: Suggest to add RECOMMENDED and OPTIONAL.
column25: We use the same conformance terms as are used in the FHIR core specification and as are conventionally used in other HL7 specifications.  "recommended" corresponds to SHOULD and 'optional' would typically correspond to MAY.

column14: • MAY describes optional behaviors that are free to consider but where the is no recommendation for or against adoption.
column15: • MAY describes optional behaviors that are free to consider but where there is no recommendation for or against adoption.
column17: Add 'there'
column25: Auto-approved

column16:
This specification could be seen as a CDS Hooks profile on CDS Services – There should a way to express this in CDS Hooks CDS Service definitions.
Accepting these services will imply that the EMR supports the requirements needed to work with these services.
column17: There should a way to express this in CDS Hooks CDS Service definitions.
column25: This is feedback that should be provided to the CDS Hooks specification.  This implementation guide complies with the current capabilities/limitations for how CDS Hooks permits services to be defined.

column14: At this time, it is not clear whether this capability will be of interest to EHR systems or other types of decision support services. Therefore, rather than proposing a change to the base CDS Hook specification, this IG will leverage the CDS Hook extension mechanism. Connectathon and implementation experience may support requesting these changes or some variant of them in a future version of the CDS Hook specification.
column16:
I propose that we add a FHIRPath expression to the CDS Service definition. This expression can, based on the prefetch results, indictare whether the CDS Service should be called.
EMR support for his would be SHOULD.
column17: I propose that we add a FHIRPath expression to the CDS Service definition
column25: This is a comment that should be made against the CDS Hooks standard.  It is out of scope for CRD until such time as the capability exists and it becomes appropriate for this guide to assert conformance expectations with respect to it.

column14: The extension here will be called davinci-crd.configuration-options. It will be a configuration object that will contain an array of available options. Each option will include four mandatory elements:
column16: I assume the configuration options can be selected by the EMR in a service configuration menu? The text seams to suggest this but this should be clarified further.
column17: I assume the configuration options can be selected by the EMR in a service configuration menu?
column25: Will clarify that the expectation is that the EMR SHOULD expose the configuration options and allow specifying values

column14: Each option will include four mandatory elements:
column15: Each option SHALL  include four mandatory elements:
column17: will -> Shall

column14: It will be a configuration object that will contain an array of available options. Each option will include four mandatory elements:
column16: Add a default value for each option.
column17: Add a default value for each option.
column25: Will add an 'optional' default element to make visible to the user what the default will be if they don't specify an override.

column14: When invoking a hook, the client system can convey any supported configuration options as part of the invocation of the hook. This will be done using the davinci-crd.configuration extension
column15: When invoking a hook, the client system SHOULD convey any supported configuration options as part of the invocation of the hook. This will be done using the davinci-crd.configuration extension
column17: Make configuration options a SHOULD
column21: If we do this, will need to wordsmith given that support for this is optional.  However, if supported and a configuration option has been selected, sending the option would presumably be a SHALL

column14: • Inclusion of configuration information in a hook call SHALL be optional (i.e. no hook invocation is permitted to fail because configuration information was not included).
column15: • Inclusion of configuration information in a hook call ís RECOMMENDED (i.e. no hook invocation is permitted to fail because configuration information was not included).
column16: SHALL be optional equals to SHOULD/RECOMMENDED
column17: SHALL be optional equals to SHOULD/RECOMMENDED
column25: Reword to: "CDS Servers SHALL NOT require the inclusion of configuration information in a hook call  (i.e. no hook invocation is permitted to fail because configuration information was not included)."

column14: Note: Recognizing these tokens doesn’t mean the client must support prefetch or the requested prefetch query, only that it recognizes the token, doesn’t treat it as an error and - if it supports the query - substitutes the token correctly.
column16: Client or CDS Server?
column17: Client or CDS Server?
column25: It's referring to the CDS Client - the one that's invoking the hook and potentially performing the pre-fetch queries.  A service identifying desired prefetches doesn't obligate the client (e.g. EHR) to providing those.

resource": {

        "status": "ready",
column17: instantiatesCanonical -> instantiatesUri
column25: This is a formal reference to a resource by its cannonical URL and therefore instantiatesCanonical is the correct element to use.  (instantiatesUri would be for pointing to a PDF or web page or something like that.)

column16: is already covered by the transaction processing rules. Can be removed.
column17: is already covered by the transaction processing rules. Can be removed.
column25: The results coming back from a hook are not a FHIR Transaction - and thus those rules don't automatically apply.  This specification therefore needs to specify the rules (though it does align with the FHIR rules for a Transaction Bundle.

column16: Systems, clients, payers, servers, EMR systems, … multiple expressions are used. In CDSHooks there is the EMR, a CDS Server and the CDS. Please define what each of these terms means and how they map on the CDS Hooks terminology and use them consistently.
column17: Be consistent with terms
column25: Will use the term 'Client' and 'Server' when referring to systems.

column14: book. Client systems conforming to this implementation guide SHALL support at least one of the hooks listed below and SHOULD support all that apply to the context of their system.
column15: book. Client systems conforming to this implementation guide SHOULD support at least one of the hooks listed below and SHOULD support all that apply to the context of their system.
column16: Why require that they support at least one of the new ones? Isn’t that up to the CDS?
column17: Why require that they support at least one of the new ones? Isn’t that up to the CDS?
column25: If the client system doesn't support at least one, then it's not doing anything covered by the IG and has no right to claim conformance to the IG.

column14: book. Client systems conforming to this implementation guide SHALL support at least one of the hooks listed below and SHOULD support all that apply to the context of their system.
column15: book. Client systems conforming to this implementation guide SHALL support at least one of the hooks listed below and should support all that apply to the context of their system.
column16: There is no to use SHOULD here as this is a implementation suggestion and not a requirement for interoperability.
column17: There is no to use SHOULD here as this is a implementation suggestion and not a requirement for interoperability.
column25: SHOULD statements are never firm 'requirements'.  They are recommendations about appropriate behavior to maximize interoperability.  Supporting all relevant hooks will maximize interoperability between EHR and Payers and thus is an appropriate statement to make

column14: For example, a payer that only provides drug coverage would never have coverage information to return on an encounter-discharge event. Payer systems conforming to this implementation guide SHALL provide a service for at least one of the hook types listed below and SHOULD support all hooks relevant to the types of coverage they provide.
column16: duplicate - remove
column17: duplicate - remove
column25: The previous set of statements was with respect to clients.  This is with respect to servers.  Both sets of statements are needed

column14: Clients and payers MAY choose to support additional hooks that are relevant to Coverage Requirements Discovery as well - both hooks appearing in the registry on the CDS Hooks website and custom hooks defined elsewhere.
column16:
MAY does not make sense. The CDS service will support all hooks that it requires. The EMR must do so as well. What happens when the CDS Server does not? Is there some way to detect this? Is the CDS service not not required to deal with the situation where it does not?
suggest to make it lower case.
column17: MAY does not make sense.
column25: The purpose of this statement is to make clear that the CRD implementation guide isn't intended to limit either clients or servers from supporting additional hooks.  Obviously interoperability would only occur in those situations where clients and servers happen to support the same ones.  However, they can coordinate to achieve that end.  Such collaborations might lead to proposals to add additional hooks in the future

column16: It all depends on where the services are hosted. For local services this is not required as they can access the CDR. For remote services this is essential as otherwise they cannot operate. Maybe defining a ‘profile’ for each of these cases would be a good idea.
column17: Maybe defining a ‘profile’ for each of these cases would be a good idea.
column25: Remote vs. local has no influence on accessibility.  CDS-Hooks allows remote servers to query the client's (i.e. EHR's) server.  As well, we expect all payer CDS servers will be remote from the EHRs, so dual profiles are unnecessary.

column16: Are these suggestions intentional informational? I would expect that most may’s and should’s should be uppercase
column17: Are these suggestions intentional informational? I would expect that most may’s and should’s should be uppercase
column25: Will go through and search for all "should", "shall" and "may" and replace them either with SHOULD, SHALL or MAY or alternative words that leave no confusion - based on the degree of conformance intention.

column14: Of the card types here, conformant client systems SHALL support the External reference and Instructions responses. They SHOULD support the remainder. Payer servers SHALL support at least one of these response type and MAY support as many as necessary to convey the requirements of the types of coverage they support.
column16:
This is confusing.
Are these formal card types, like profiles? In this case, the sub-sections should require something. and a more strict specification format may be required. 
Otherwise state the CDS-Hooks spec elements that are required.
column17: Are these formal card types, like profiles?
column25: Change from "card types" to "response types" and at the beginning of the section that the "response types" are not formally identified in the cards, but instead reflect CRD-specific profiles on the cards that describe CRD-expected behavior.

column14: Of the card types here, conformant client systems SHALL support the External reference and Instructions responses. They SHOULD support the remainder. Payer servers SHALL support at least one of these response type and MAY support as many as necessary to convey the requirements of the types of coverage they support.
column16: May other formats also be supported?
column17: May other formats also be supported?
column25: The specification already says that other card types either SHOULD or MAY be supported (depending on client or server and whether described in CRD or not).  Content not supported by CDS Hooks is outside the scope of this specification.

column16: Where does the resulting QuestionnaireResponse go to? Suggets to link to SDC for such functionality.

column14: This suggestion will always include a “create” action for the Task. The Task will point to the questionnaire to be completed using the Task.input property with a Task.input.name of “questionnaire”. That Questionnaire might be included with a separate conditional “create” action or might be excluded with the presumption it will already be available or retrievable by the client via its canonical URL from the original source or from a local registry. The Task.code will always include the CRD-specific complete-questionnaire code. The reason for completion will be conveyed in Task.reasonCode.
column16: It could also be a contained resource in the Task.
column17: It could also be a contained resource in the Task.
column25: Contained resources are only used if they are only relevant in the context of the containing resource.  We don't expect there to be any Questionnaires that are specific to a single patient order, so containment would not be appropriate.  (Containment is never to be used as just a convenient transport mechanism.)

column14: This suggestion will always include a “create” action for the Task. The Task will point to the questionnaire to be completed using the Task.input property with a Task.input.name of “questionnaire”. That Questionnaire might be included with a separate conditional “create” action or might be excluded with the presumption it will already be available or retrievable by the client via its canonical URL from the original source or from a local registry. The Task.code will always include the CRD-specific complete-questionnaire code. The reason for completion will be conveyed in Task.reasonCode.
column16:
A suggestion to fill in  questionnaire could also be signalled using a ServiceRequest with a servicerequest-questionnaireRequest  extension?
Why use a Task instead?
column17:
A suggestion to fill in  questionnaire could also be signalled using a ServiceRequest with a servicerequest-questionnaireRequest  extension?
Why use a Task instead?
column25: Task is the preferred way of capturing and tracking "to do" items.  ServiceRequest (as all requests) represents an 'authorization' and doesn't necessarily represent something that is immediately actionable.

column14: This suggestion will always include a “create” action for the Task. The Task will point to the questionnaire to be completed using the Task.input property with a Task.input.name of “questionnaire”. That Questionnaire might be included with a separate conditional “create” action or might be excluded with the presumption it will already be available or retrievable by the client via its canonical URL from the original source or from a local registry. The Task.code will always include the CRD-specific complete-questionnaire code. The reason for completion will be conveyed in Task.reasonCode.
column16: Alternatively, there could be a link referring to a SmartApp that shows the questionnaire. Is this somehting that should be provided as an alternative implementation of this card?
column17: Alternatively, there could be a link referring to a SmartApp that shows the questionnaire.
column21: The trick with pointing to a SMART app is that it would have to be a SMART app that is supported by the EHR.  In general, it won't be practical to have separate apps for each Questionnaire.  Though perhaps a generic SMART App that you pass a token to that indicates the Questionnaire and context could work.

column16:

column21: Can SMART apps access and manipulate 'draft' orders/appointments/etc?  At minimum we should add language that indicates that SMART apps could potentially allow the user to store tasks (such as completing Questionanires)

column16: I do not think that HL7 should provde requirements on software engineers. Remove SHALL.

column25: It's quite common for IGs to assert security expectations on systems.  The whole point of IGs is to set expectations for implementation.  However, we can reword to "Implementions SHALL adhere to" to avoid a possible perception of limiting implementers to only those who are already familiar with.

column14: • Payer systems SHALL use information received solely for coverage determination purposes and SHALL NOT retain received over the CRD interfaces for any purpose other than audit
column15: • Payer systems SHALL use information received solely for coverage determination purposes and SHALL NOT retain received data over the CRD interfaces for any purpose other than audit
column17: Add 'data'
column25: Auto-approved

column14: • Client systems SHALL ensure that the resource identifiers exposed over the CRD interface are distinct from and have no determinable relationship with any business identifiers associated with those records. E.g. the Patient.id element cannot be the same as or contain in some fashion a patient’s social security number or medical record number.
column16: Basically you have to provide de-indentifiable data? If so, then I suggest stating this.
column17: Basically you have to provide de-indentifiable data? If so, then I suggest stating this.
column25: This is not a general de-identifiable data requirement.  It's simply imposing a constraint that the resource id not expose personally identifying information.

column14: Some payers may not have legal permission to view patient-identifiable healthcare information (PHI) for coverage requirements discovery purposes. EMR systems SHALL support filtering exposed FHIR resources to be a non-PHI “redacted” view. This view SHALL ensure that all resources exposed through the CDS Hooks and SMART on FHIR interfaces are filtered as follows:
column16: It seams to be to strict to require this also for EMR's that do not work with such payers. Is SHALL really required? Suggest to remove SHALL.
column17: It seams to be to strict to require this also for EMR's that do not work with such payers.
column25: EMRs are free to not comply with this IG (though their customers may have some problems getting paid by CMS in the future).  But if they conform with this IG, then the expectation is that they SHALL have this behavior.  It's a US industry requirement.

column14: Client systems SHALL determine whether a payer system should receive the PHI or non-PHI version of the CRD interface at the time the payer is configured to have access to their system.

column14: 1. Practitioners will rely on the information provided by the Coverage Requirements Discovery process to determine if there are any special steps they need to take such as requesting prior authorization. As a result, it’s important to them to know definitively whether requirements exist or not. While potentially noisy, payers SHALL provide a message that says “No coverage requirements for [ABC]” if it is definitively known that there are no requirements for the proposed action or “Unable to determine coverage requirements for [ABC] - please review [XYZ]” or some equivalent when processing errors (e.g. unrecognized service code) prevent the payer from determining coverage requirements.
column16:
This seams to be in contrast with earlier stantements on the reduction of the number of cards.
What is the required/advised communication approach? Is it wise to include a separate section where this is explained together?
column17: This seams to be in contrast with earlier stantements on the reduction of the number of cards.
column25: This is considered to be essential information for clinicians to have.  If they have no information about whether there are requirements, then they're going to make phone calls or otherwise investigate whether there are rules, so being told "no rules" results in saved time and is not considered "noise".

column14: . As well, all Card.suggestion elements SHALL populate the Suggestion.uuid element to aid in logging.

column16: Support for standard vocabularies is needed to enable these interactions.  E.g., example vocabulary bindings is insufficient to identify what type of appointment or procedure is being proposed.  Vs. for medications, the use of RxNorm codes would enable this type of functionality. Similar issue when proposing orders -- need specification and adoption of standards (e.g., SNOMED CT for procedures, as more than example binding). Recommend working with US Core to tighten vocabulary bindings to enable this use case, e.g., for procedures.
column17: Need to support standard vocabularies to know what is being proposed as an order
column21: We could find the comment not related and tell them to complain to US Core.  However, we should vet that US Core is sufficiently tight to be useful for our purposes.

column16: For encounter-start, need to clarify what the expectations is for the external to facility -> ED -> inpatient transition.  E.g., is transitioning from ED to inpatient considered a separate encounter-start event?  The term "patient is admitted" would seem to indicate it's the ED -> inpatient transtiion, not when the patient first arrived at ED.  Should clarify.
column17: Clarify semantics of encounter-start with regard to transition from ED to hospital floor.
column25: It's not within our scope to try to standardize hospital administrative practices.  Encounter boundaries are determined by business practice, not by FHIR.  The CDS Hooks will trigger based on where they fit into the EHR workflow.  When users choose to invoke particular points of the workflow is not within our control.

column25: It's not currently a SHALL.  Feel free to comment if we tighten it to a SHALL in the future.  However, the purpose of an IG is to tighten expectations, so it would be legitimate to mandate something for CRD conformance that isn't mandatory in general.  That said, agree that - at least in the US - mandating this for CRD would essentially mandate support most places.

column14: NOTE: this won’t necessarily occur each time the EMR or CRD app makes a call to the server as the payer server requirements are expected to be static and can therefore be cached.
column16: This single sentence is the only reference to a CRD client's ability to cache cards. When should or can a client cache a card? For how long? How does the client know that a card is stale? How does the client know when a card is specific to a patient, plan or payer -- and therefore should only be re-used under specific circumstances? It feels like this sentence was added after the fact to assuage performance concerns but the full details weren't thought through or accounted for. I think this sentence should be deleted.
column17: Remove sentence about caching static requirements because the IG doesn't actually enable it.
column25: This isn't about caching cards, it's about caching payer CDS service requirements (e.g. what their pre-fetch desires are, what hooks they support, etc.)

column14: 2b. Provider starts ‘CRD what-if’
column16: Is there a functional, technical difference between the "EMR" and the "CRD app" in the IG? Is any of this IG actually limited to an "EMR" or CRD app?  I don't think that it is. Other types of software should be able to use CRD to call a CRD Service. These two actors should be collapsed into a single and more generic actor. Note that CDS Hooks refers to this actor as a CDS Client. In the "Formal Spec" page, section 4.1.3 Systems, you actually define your terms for these actors, but them fail to use those terms consistently. I'd recommend the terms CRD Client and CRD Service for accuracy.
column17: Remove references to CRD app; rename "EMR" to CRD client.
column25: CRD app refers to a SMART app launched from the EMR rather than the EMR itself.  Will replace all references to CRD app with CRD SMART app

column14: The provider uses their EMR to launch a ‘What if?’ CRD app that allows them to explore payer coverage requirements. The provider indicates the type of action they’re considering and the CRD app prompts for additional information relevant to coverage determination, such as the proposed drug, type of referral or appointment, etc.
column16: CDS Hooks distniguishes between the lack of a response from a CDS service and the lack of guidance. It seems like the absence of coverage requirements should not generate an alert to a user.
column17: No coverage requirements' should not create a card.
column21: See #80

column14: A message describing what coverage requirements exist … The requirements themselves might include …  medical documentation that must exist or be provided
column16: Returning a card with textual description of a requirement of medical documentation should only be done after the payer has verified against the provider's FHIR server that this documentation does not exist.
column17: Don't unnecessarily interrupt the provider
column21: My impression is that a lot of payers wouldn't initially be capable of querying data (and even when capable, might not be permitted to see it), so not sure if we should make this recommendation and, if so, how strong we can make it.

column16: A reference implementation of a simulated "what-if" CRD client should not be referenced in the IG except as a implementation artifact and potential resource to implementers. As it is, it's unclear if the use of this single, specific web application is a required to support CRD.
column17: Use of the "Da Vinci CRD SMART app" should not be required to conform to CRD and should not be referenced explicitly in normative IG content.
column21: The SMART app is the only mechanism we have to support "what if" invocation of the decision support interface (i.e. without actually going through the order/referral/appointment/etc. creation process).  What-if support is a firm requirement of the project.  (The alternative is that EMRs provide what-if capability baked into their systems, but there was little interest in doing that.)

column14: Clients conforming with this application SHALL support the SMART on FHIR interface, allow launching of SMART apps from within their application and be capable of providing the SMART app access to the same resources it exposes to payer systems using the CDS Hooks interface.
column16: Note that the CDS Hooks specification differentiates contextual FHIR resources sent from the CDS client in the request from RESTful FHIR queries because there are cases in a user's workflow where an unsigned order or draft resource might not yet have been persisted to the database, but yet benefit from external CDS. This context/pre-fetch "push" of FHIR to the external CDS service is a unique capability that doesn't (currently) exist in SMART.
column17: SMART app can't always access same FHIR resources as a CDS Service.

column14: Implementers SHALL be familiar with and adhere to any security and privacy rules defined by:
column15: Implementations SHALL adhere to any security and privacy rules defined by:
column16: The IG defines the word SHALL -- "SHALL indicates requirements that must be met to be conformant with the specification." and then also says "Implementers SHALL be familiar with and adhere to any security and privacy rules defined …". Can this IG really tell implementers (and not just implementations) what to do? Can implementers, living people, be conformant with CRD?
column17: Change implementers SHALL to implementations SHALL
column21: See #27

column14: Communications between providers and payers SHALL use mutually authenticated TLS. **
column16: This requirement adds significant implementation burden and provides little to no advantages and diverges the the foundational specifications on which CRD is built. Further, the IG doesn't assist with key discovery or rotation or actually explain when mutual TLS is required (RESTful FHIR? SMART app launch?). As the IG says, there's already significant security mechanisms in the underlying SMART and CDS Hooks specifications. If those mechanisms are deemed insufficient, the base specs should be updated, CRD shouldn't add it's own, additional and expensive security requirements on top of this stack.
column17: Remove mutual TLS requirement

column14: Client systems SHALL support running applications that adhere to the SMART on FHIR public app profile
column16: This seems like an arbitrary requirement that is outside the basic purpose of the IG. Further, this requirement reduces security.
column17: Allow client to require more secure, confidential SMART apps.

column14: Payer systems that wish to receive Hook invocations that contain PHI SHALL demonstrate at time of registration/configuration that their user agreements give them permission to receive such data in a coverage requirement context.
column16: This requirement doesn't belong in a technical specification. This is a business requirement.
column17: Don't mandate business requirements in a FHIR IG.

column14: However, client systems withholding information take on the responsibility of ensuring coverage requirements are met, even if discovery is no longer possible through the interfaces provided by this implementation guide.
column16: Does this belong in an interoperability standard?
column17: Don't mandate legal or  business requirements in a FHIR IG.

column14: Client systems SHALL determine whether a payer system should receive the PHI or non-PHI version of the CRD interface at the time the payer is configured to have access to their system.
column16: The split between PHI and non-PHI CRD services burdens the CRD Client and favors the CRD service. There are many more clients than services. This IG introduces essentially new FHIR resources to support this non-PHI scenario, including the somewhat nonsensical non-PHI Patient resource. Optimally, all CRD services would support a single set of PHI hooks. That's the best case scenario that would most likely accomplish the desired interoperability and improvements in care and cost. CRD clients should not be required to support the non-standard and less-functional non-PHI hooks.
column17: Don't require CRD clients to support both PHI and non-PHI

column14: Practitioners will rely on the information provided by the Coverage Requirements Discovery process to determine if there are any special steps they need to take such as requesting prior authorization. As a result, it’s important to them to know definitively whether requirements exist or not. While potentially noisy, payers SHALL provide a message that says “No coverage requirements for [ABC]” if it is definitively known that there are no requirements for the proposed action or “Unable to determine coverage requirements for [ABC] - please review [XYZ]” or some equivalent when processing errors (e.g. unrecognized service code) prevent the payer from determining coverage requirements.
column16: CDS Hooks distniguishes between the lack of a response from a CDS service and the lack of guidance. It seems like the absence of coverage requirements should not generate an alert to a user. This approach is perfectly designed to generate provider burden: "While potentially noisy, payers SHALL provide a message that says “No coverage requirements for [ABC]” if it is definitively known that there are no requirements for the proposed action". Also, specifically note that an empty json object (the CDS Hooks mechanism for representing no guidance -- which is not shown to the user) allows a computer to distinguish between "no requirements" and a textual requirement (this is relevent to 4.5.2).
column17: No coverage requirements' should not create a card.
column21: The challenge here is that clinicans often have a specific need to know whether there are coverage requirements.  As such, failure to differentiate between "no requirements exist" from "coverage requirements might exist, but the service was unavailable, errored out, was unable to make a determination, etc" is important.  If the clinician doesn't receive confirmation about whether coverage requirements exist, then they'll fall back on the old process of phoning/faxing/etc. to find out - which is the whole process this IG is intended to avoid.

column14: It might be possible to configure a service to withhold certain card types from certain practitioner roles, the servicing provider, or specific users. However, doing so will create process challenges to manage such customization requests and would place a considerable configuration burden on payer software.
column16: The ability to insert content into a clinician's workflow -- especially their ordering workflow, carries substantial risk of increasing physician burden. All of CRD and it's base spec, CDS Hooks, includes this risk. In exchange for accepting this risk, CRD and CDS clients achieve the ability to significantly interact with a provider's workflow in realtime. Responsibility for delivering useful guidance and just as importantly, not interrupting the provider with useless guidance must fall on the system that's generating and delivering the guidance. This follows a basic separation of concerns. CRD services must take on the responsibility of crafting their guidance so that it is useful.
column17: CRD services must be responsible for delivering useful guidance.

column16: The lack of a standardized set of "configuration options" means that every CRD service could likely name their options differently. Each CRD client must manually read and parse and consider the impact of requesting specific types of content from the service. It would be better to place the responsibility for delivering useful content on the service that owns the content. Failing that, the same CRD request should work against any and every CRD service.
column17: Interoperability means CRD clients needn't redevelop or reconfigure for one payer to the next
column21: The intention was to define a generic configuration communication mechanism that would not require EMR systems to behave differently, though each organization that enables a particular service would need to set configuration options

column14: The Questionnaire will only be created if it didn’t already exist:
column16: Why can't the CRD service query the CDS Client's FHIR service to determine if the Questionnaire resource exists; instead of adding all of this complexity in an extension?
column17: Wouldn't use of RESTful FHIR eliminate the need for the if-non-exists extension?
column21: Some systems can't query anything that doesn't come in the pre-fetch  - and at pre-fetch time, they won't know what questionnaires to look for.

column14: The client SHOULD display to the user that the Server Coverage Requirements Discovery Service is unavailable.
column16: What is a provider supposed to do with an alert indicating that a CRD service is unavailalbe? Should they not place their order? The CRD IG should not prescribe UI behavior on CRD clients.
column17: Don't prescribe UI behavior.
column21: The user should fall back on their normal coverage determination process - pick up the phone (or more commonly, have their staff do so)

column14: This hook would be triggered when a provider books a future appointment for the patient with themselves or their own organization as well as when they book an appointment for a patient with someone else.
column16: It would be nice to update the definition of the appointment-book hook on the CDS Hooks site to include the additional workflow information provided in the CRD IG.
column17: Add add'l workflow description to CDS Hooks
column25: Will do this

column16: Should appointment-book actually support PractitionerRole as a user? The rest of the hooks don't (see zulip discussion).
column17: Is PractitionerRole a user?
column21: Which thread?  PractitionerRole is a user tied to a specific capacity and organization - as opposed to just a person with a license independent of who they're working for or what they're doing

column14: Potential drug-drug interactions based on exiting payer knowledge
column15: Potential drug-drug interactions based on existing payer knowledge
column16: Misspelling of existing
column17: Misspelling of existing
column25: Auto-approved

column16: Support optionality for this extension is not defined. Is this SHOULD or SHALL; for clients, for servers?
column17: Is `if-none-exist` required?

column14: information should be delivered efficiently and be tuned to provide maximum relevance.
column16: Why isn't there formal optionality language in this section?
column17: Is card usability a MAY, SHOULD or MUST?
column21: Mainly because this is hard requirement to evaluate conformance to

column16: When reasonable, an "External Reference" card SHOULD contain a summary of the actionable information from the external reference. Maybe this is a mix of Instructions and External Reference?
column17: When reasonable, an "External Reference" card SHOULD contain a summary of the actionable information from the external reference.

column14: The queries use the defined search parameter names from the respective FHIR specification versions. If parties processing these queries have varied from these ‘standard’ search parameter names, they will be responsible for translating the parameters into their local names.
column16: This wording in the spec seems to be a tautology and therefore of limited usefulness -- if "parties" are using custom names, the standard names won't work …
column17: What is this sentence intended to communicate?
column25: In FHIR, the names for query parameters are *recommended* names but are not mandated.  The actual names used by a given server are determined by the SearchParameter canonical URLs tied to each name by the server-specific CapabilityStatement.  This statement is saying that the prefetch queries presume 'standard' names.  If the EMR uses non-standard names, the queries will have to be adjusted accordingly.  (This should probably be guidance in the CDS Hooks spec.)

column14: Information relevant to the context of a specific hook invocation SHOULD always be queried using the provided token, not included in prefetch.
column16: Can this sentence be rewritten to be more clear? This phrase: "information relevent to the context of a specific hook invocation" is too many words for the reader to quickly understand the intended meaning. Also, "queried using the provided token" is a very roundabout way to mean -- retrieved from the FHIR server. An example would really, really help.
column17: Can we rewrite this sentence for clarity?
column21: What would be better wording

column14: EMR implementations should not expect standardized prefetch key names.
column16: It seems like standardizing prefetch key names would be a great opportunity to simply and easily reduce optionality as part of this IG. Why not standardize them?
column17: Why not standardize prefetch key names?
column25: The specific pre-fetch queries used by different payers will vary - due to the obligation to retrieve "minimum necessary".  The queries provided show what EMRs SHOULD support, but not what the actual prefetch queries form individual payers will actually be.  As such, there's no benefit to trying to standardize.  (As well, the underlying standard requires systems to look at the supplied queries anyhow, so standardizing wouldn't save much.)

column16: In the wild, there's little production support for NutrionOrder, VisionPrescription, and limited support for DeviceRequest and ReferralRequest. Elsewhere in the IG, you've set expectations with the reader when a feature may not work (pre-fetch, itself, for example). Is RESTful support of these resources a SHALL in this IG for clients?
column17: Is support for these resources a requirement for CRD clients?
column21: Lloyd: Is there guidance we want to supply about which/how many must be supported?

column14: When full prefetch as defined here is not supported, client systems SHALL, at minimum, support the batch query syntax shown above. Payer systems may choose to support the batch query mechanism, perform client-specific queries as necessary or return no results when a client does not support its prefetch requirements.
column15: When full prefetch as defined here is not supported, client systems SHOULD, at minimum, support the batch query syntax shown above. Payer systems may choose to support the batch query mechanism, perform client-specific queries as necessary or return no results when a client does not support its prefetch requirements.
column16: This section of the IG mandates CRD clients to support either the CRD-specific (non-standard per CDS Hooks) pre-fetch or FHIR batch query; yet, the CRD service is given more flexibility. This SHALL should be a SHOULD.
column17: Allow CRD client to support individual RESTful queries instead of FHIR batch query.
column21: Do we want to allow individual queries?  The EMRs will prefer this, but it is going to mean more calls and/or increase payer complexity.  (Alternatively - are we confident that it's reasonable to expect all EMRs to support Batch queries?)

column14: Services SHOULD provide what coverage requirements they can based on the information available.
column15: Services SHALL provide what coverage requirements they can based on the information available.
column16: Why isn't this a SHALL? If a CRD service doesn't return coverage requirements based on available information even though it "can"; that service ought not to be compliant with the IG.
column17: Services should be required to provide what coverage requirements they're able to based on available information.
column25: Make this SHALL

column14: 1. The examples in this guide use whitespace for readability. Conformance systems SHOULD omit non-significant whitespace for performance reasons
column16: Does this belong in a FHIR IG? Regardless of the merit of the recommendation; this should either be in the core FHIR spec or not a recommendation at all. This is way outside the core domain of the IG.
column17: Why does CRD recommend how FHIR whitespace is handled?
column25: Implementers commonly implement examples "as seen".  The purpose of the comment was to call attention to the fact that a more concise syntax is desired.  While some implementers may find the recommendation unnecessary, those being targeted by the comment will not.

column14:
Providers need to easily discover which payer covered services or devices have:

Specific documentation requirements,

Rules for determining need for specific treatments/services

Requirement for Prior Authorization (PA) or other approvals

Specific guidance.
column15:
Providers need to easily discover which payer covered services or devices have:

Specific documentation requirements,

Rules for determining need for specific treatments/services,

Requirement for Prior Authorization (PA) or other approvals,

and Specific guidance.
column16: Needs comma at the end of each bullet except last one. Add and before last bullet
column17: Needs comma at the end of each bullet except last one. Add and before last bullet
column25: Auto-approved (put 'and' following comma on third bullet)

column14: Dr. Jones completes the necessary paperwork to initiate a prior authorization and sends the relevant supporting information to the imaging center as part of the referral.
column15: Dr. Good completes the necessary paperwork to initiate a prior authorization and sends the relevant supporting information to the imaging center as part of the referral.
column16: Doctors name is Good
column17: Doctors name is Good
column25: Auto-approved

column16: As technology continues to break down previous access barriers to patient data, particular care needs to be shown to ensure that providers are only sharing RELEVANT, appropriate data.  This is particularly important given the forthcoming information blocking/EHI regulations from ONC.  There is a growing concern from medical professional organizations that some entities may leverage information blocking as a tool to open up a physician's EHR and extract more info than necessary.  Monitoring controls must be established and built into the inherent design of technology to limit potential abuse.  This is especially important fiven the impact on patients' privacy rights.
column17: The ballot needs to ensure that the provider is aware of what information will be collected from their EHR by payer systems in order to determine a coverage requirement.

column16:
In order to ensure the intended efficiencies, any program linked in a response should be launchable without additional log-in information.  Additionally, the information entered therein should be used to supplement information contained in the EHR, rather than require reentry of data found within the provider’s system. 

Any linked programs returned on the CRD should not require additional log-in and should only be used to obtain information that could not otherwise have been obtained in the EHR.
column17: Don't require extra log-in
column21: Do we want to add any additional guidance here?

column16:
The baseline should always be acceptable.  We do not want to require physician systems to have to support a potentially infinite number of idiosyncratic payer systematic needs, as this could be overly burdensome. 

In keeping with the intentions of Revenue Cycle Standards, the guide should establish a baseline that, if adhered to, must be received and accepted by payers as an acceptably formatted transaction.
column17: Minimize payer-specific variation
column21: Do we want to prohibit payer systems from demanding more than the base specification?  (We certainly don't want to prohibit them from *allowing* more.)

column16: It is troubling to see a yet to be released technology as the technological base for our ballot.  Our ballot heavily references CDS Hooks, which is still potentially under significant revision processes, thus making this ballot effectively asking for comments on something that might change significantly.
column17: It is difficult to effectively provide commentary on whether we agree with a technology that is still yet to be published.
column25: CDS Hooks has passed STU ballot and has been published.  At the time of ballot, the specification referenced the 'final' version of the specification that was awaiting publication.  The referenced specification has proven sufficient to support implementation of numerous implementations in a wide variety of EMR, payer and other systems, so it should have been more than adequate to evaluate.

column14: BALLOT NOTE:  This proposed pre-adoption is not CDS Hooks conformant. It is possible that the CDS Hooks community will adopt an alternative solution or may even choose not to make any changes.
column16: Seems as though the technology should be ironed out by CDS Hooks before pursuing a ballot that builds upon it.
column17: Seems as though the technology should be ironed out by CDS Hooks before pursuing a ballot that builds upon it.

column16: The ProcedureRequest and ServiceRequest feature SNOMED as the example language used to convey a procedure between a payer and provider.  Currently, both fee for service and alternative payment models utilize CPT for identifying services.  The implementation guide should reflect these usage models and should include usage of CPT as the example codeset for these scenarios
column17: Use CPT, not SNOMED for procedures

column14: Suggestions>Type>"coding">"display": "Amoxicillin 200 MG Oral Tablet"
column16: Prescription drugs are ordered using the SCRIPT NCPDP e-Prescribing standard.  NCPDP is also currently developing a real time pharmacy benefit transaction that would seem to perform the same function.  To date, DaVinci has been presented as focused on medical services transactions.  Recommend removing any usage/mention of any drugs, unless they are applicable to the medical benefit (rather than the prescription benefit).
column17: Prescription drugs should not be used in equations.

column14: Some payers may not have legal permission to view patient-identifiable healthcare information (PHI) for coverage requirements discovery purposes. EMR systems SHALL support filtering exposed FHIR resources to be a non-PHI “redacted” view.Some payers may not have legal permission to view patient-identifiable healthcare information (PHI) for coverage requirements discovery purposes. EMR systems SHALL support filtering exposed FHIR resources to be a non-PHI “redacted” view.
column16: The guides need to be clearer on guardrails that will protect patient privacy rights.  In order to be trusted safeguards of patient data, physicians cannot be forced to allow overly broad access to medical records without sufficient justification.  With this concept in mind, PHI access should be limited only to situations where it is specifically needed to make a decision.
column17: Recommend making the standard usage as "non-PHI Hook invocation", only using PHI when such information is essential to determining coverage requirements.

column14: “Unable to determine coverage requirements for [ABC] - please review [XYZ]” or some equivalent when processing errors
column16: The second clause of this sentence is particularly important, as it points to a specific technical error or issue to be resolved in order to make the CRD processable.  In order to prevent a situation where a payer can simply say "We are not sure… this is pended", which often results in the need for a phone call and can delay care, there needs to be an avenue to addressing any shortcoming conveyed up front.
column17: There needs to be an avenue to addressing any shortcoming conveyed up front.
column25: We agree this would be desirable, however there is no guarantee that there will always be a computable mechanism to communicate what's needed to resolve a payer's issues.  Our objective is to significantly reduce the situation where a phone call is needed, but we're under no illusions that they'll ever be totally eliminated from the process.

column14: Therefore, in addition to any logging performed for security purposes both clients and servers SHALL retain logs of all CRD-related hook invocations and their responses that can be accessed in the event of a dispute by authorized personnel. As well, all Card.suggestion elements SHALL populate the Suggestion.uuid element to aid in logging.
column16: This is an important feature.  We encourage exploration and development of a standard method for an authorized user to easily access this information as needed..
column17: We encourage exploration and development of a standard method for an authorized user to easily access this information as needed..
column21: Typically, log information is not exposed outside of an organization.  Within an organization, there's no need for a standard interface.  Is there any interest/use-case for doing this or should we find it non-persuasive?

column16: 1) The ballot is undergoing several updates pending connectathon and additional testing results
column17: The ballot is undergoing several updates pending connectathon and additional testing results
column25: That is true.  It's unclear why that justifies a negative ballot.  As a standard for trial use, there is expected to be a period of ballot, implement, adjust, reballot as the community gains implementation experience and adjusts the specification to best meet its needs

column16: 2) several parts of the ballot reference proposals recently submitted to correct external resources or proposal that are still pending to be resolved
column17: Several parts of the ballot reference proposals recently submitted to correct external resources or proposal that are still pending to be resolved
column25: That is true.  It's not clear why that's a rationale for a negative vote.  This specification is intended to be implementable - not necessarily locked down or totally stable.  (Under HL7 rules, a totally locked down standard wouldn't be possible for about 4 years - after considerable implementation experience.)  We have specifically highlighted those parts where proposals are in progress to alert implementers as to which portions are specifically known to be vulnerable to future change.

column16: 3) the IG relies heavily on CDS-HOOKS which is still under major development
column17: The IG relies heavily on CDS-HOOKS which is still under major development
column25: CDS Hooks has passed STU ballot and has significant support (and implementation underway) by most significant US EMR vendors.  This specification is also at STU level.  CDS Hooks is not significantly less mature than any of the other possible options and is the one that's been endorsed as most appropriate by the stakeholders who will be implementing it.

column16: The Cards returned in response to a CDS Hooks query need to have some that are standardized and required to specifically indicate to the provider if a Prior Authorization is required or not for the specific service or procedure.
column17: Specifically indicate to the provider if a Prior Authorization is required or not for the specific service or procedure.
column25: There are several different types of cards that could be returned to indicate whether prior authorization is required - external reference, instructions, request form completion and/or launch SMART app.  We don't want to constrain payers and there's no particular benefit to EMRs to trying to standardize further.
